question.body: Date //
Unit:

What are your mode(s) of instruction for the following:
Lecture (select all that apply)

What are your mode(s) of instruction for the following:
Lab(Experiments) (select all that apply)

What are your mode(s) of instruction for the following:
Discussion/Recitation/Problem-Solving Session (select all that apply)
To what extent did you change what and how you taught based on use of the OLI courseware?

body.p: Check if you provided or assigned any of the following activities to be completed independently outside of class time.

multiple_choice.choice: Online test, quiz or poll question
OLI virtual lab or simulation activity
Showing or conducting a non-OLI demo, video, simulation, or experiment
Other active learning techniques: Please specify below

question.body:
If you entered other to the previous question, please provide details here.
After you have answered this question, please click "Submit and Compare" to record your answer.

If you have any way to measure student engagement, such as proportion of the class viewing or using optional elements, please describe it here, and report the metrics if possible.
After you have answered this question, please click "Submit and Compare" to record your answer.

Synchronous Lecture Activities If you personally taught a synchronous lecture section this week, estimate the percent of lecture class time you spent on each of the following activities. Note: percentages do not need to add up to 100%, we are just looking for your best guestimate.
Lecture
Group or pair discussion or problem solving
Individual Work
Clicker or poll questions
Guided Problem Solving
Test or quiz
Showing or conducting a demo, video, simulation, or experiment
Administrative tasks
Engaging in 1-on-1 discussion with a student
Other active learning techniques: Please specify below

Please estimate the proportion of students actively paying attention in your most recent non-exam class (clearly listening, even if they werenâ€™t speaking).
After you have answered this question, please click "Submit and Compare" to record your answer.

Synchronous Instructor-Led Lab or Discussion Section Activities If you personally taught a synchronous lab or discussion section this week, estimate the percent of class time you spent on each of the following activities in an average session this week. Note: percentages do not need to add up to 100%, we are just looking for your best guestimate.
Lecture
Group or pair discussion or problem solving
Individual Work
Clicker or poll questions
Guided Problem Solving
Test or quiz
Showing or conducting a demo, video, simulation, or experiment
Administrative tasks
Engaging in 1-on-1 discussion with a student
Other active learning techniques: Please specify below
Did you use any other active learning techniques in class during this past week? Check if used in lectures, lab, or discussion sections, or otherwise, then describe below. Check all that apply.

If you answered yes to the previous question, please provide details here.
After you have answered this question, please click "Submit and Compare" to record your answer.
Did you use questions from OLI in your course this week? Check if used in lectures, discussion sections, labs, homework, or otherwise, then describe below, or explain why not. Check all that apply.

Please provide details to the previous question here.
After you have answered this question, please click "Submit and Compare" to record your answer.

Did you use OLI data to choose/determine/inform what course material was covered and/or select activities for use in class (whole-class adaptation) this week? Check if used in lectures, discussion sections, or labs, then describe below, or explain why not. Check all that apply.

Please provide details to the previous question here.
After you have answered this question, please click "Submit and Compare" to record your answer.
Did you use OLI data to help meet the needs of individual students (individual adaptation) this week? If so, please describe.

Please provide details to the previous question here.
After you have answered this question, please click "Submit and Compare" to record your answer.
Did you experience any new or striking challenges from using OLI in your course this week? If so, please describe.

Please provide details to the previous question here.
After you have answered this question, please click "Submit and Compare" to record your answer.
Were there any new or striking benefits of using OLI in your course this week? If so, please describe.

Please provide details to the previous question here.
After you have answered this question, please click "Submit and Compare" to record your answer.
Have your students provided any feedback about using OLI in your course this week?

Please provide details to the previous question here.
After you have answered this question, please click "Submit and Compare" to record your answer.

What new tips or techniques did you discover this week that you would recommend to other instructors using OLI?
After you have answered this question, please click "Submit and Compare" to record your answer.

response.feedback: Incorrect. The first step is to convert from gal to L.
Correct. The first step is to convert from gal to L.
Incorrect. The first step is to convert from gal to L.
Incorrect. You want the gal unit to cancel.
Incorrect. You want the gal unit to cancel.
Correct. You want the gal unit to cancel.
Correct. The final step is to convert from L to mL.
Incorrect. The final step is to convert from L to mL.
Incorrect. The final step is to convert from L to mL.
Incorrect. You want the L unit to cancel.
Correct. You want the L unit to cancel.
Incorrect. You want the L unit to cancel.
Correct. 1 gal = 3.785 L
Incorrect. 1 gal = 3.785 L
Correct. 1 gal = 3.785 L
Incorrect. 1 gal = 3.785 L
Correct. 1 L = 1000 mL
Incorrect. 1 L = 1000 mL
Correct. 1 L = 1000 mL
Incorrect. 1 L = 1000 mL

body.p: A hot metal bar is put into a cup of cool water. What are the signs of q?

response.feedback: Correct. The cool water gains heat, which means its energy is increasing.
Incorrect. The cool water gains heat, which means its energy is increasing.
Incorrect.The hot metal loses heat, which means its energy is decreasing.
Correct. The hot metal loses heat, which means its energy is decreasing.

question.body: Have your students provided any feedback about using OLI in your course this week?

body.p: What needs to be done to the reduction half reaction to balance it? Select all that apply.

multiple_choice.choice: Add H+ to the right side of the equation.
Add electrons to the right side of the equation.
Add H+ to the left side of the equation.
Add electrons to the left side of the equation.
Add H2O to the left side of the equation.
Add H2O to the right side of the equation.
Change a coefficient to balance an element other than H and O.

response.feedback: Correct. Here only the charge needs balanced with the addition of electrons.
Incorrect. Here only the charge needs balanced with the addition of electrons.

p.em: THIS IS AN EXAMPLE MULTIPLE CHOICE QUESTION. PLEASE EDIT OR DELETE IT.

body.p: Albert sees that his girlfriend has written her password on a note beside her computer; he logs in and sends a joke email to one of her friends. This action is:

feedback.p: Incorrect; using another student's password is not acceptable, even if it's left out in the open. Further, Albert has assumed his girlfriend's identity by using her account, which is also a violation of the Computing Policy.
Correct; this is a pretty clear violation of the policy, including using another person's account and impersonating another individual.
